title: Jallianwala Bagh
description: Site of the 1919 massacre where British troops fired on a crowd of unarmed Indians, killing hundreds and galvanizing the independence movement.

title: Dandi
description: Destination of Gandhi's famous Salt March in 1930, a nonviolent protest against the British salt monopoly.

title: Chauri Chaura
description: Location of the 1922 incident that led Gandhi to call off the Non-Cooperation Movement.

title: Sabarmati Ashram
description: Gandhi's home and the starting point of the Dandi Salt March.

title: Red Fort
description: Where Jawaharlal Nehru raised the Indian flag on August 15, 1947, marking India's independence.

title: Andaman Cellular Jail
description: British prison where many freedom fighters were exiled and tortured, now a national memorial.

title: Agra Fort
description: A UNESCO World Heritage site and the seat of the Mughal Empire before Delhi. It holds historical significance for being a key administrative center during a period of British colonial rule.

title: Gateway of India
description: Built to commemorate the landing of King George V and Queen Mary in Mumbai. It became a symbolic landmark of British imperial power in India.

title: Lucknow
description: The capital of Uttar Pradesh, Lucknow was a major center of the 1857 Indian Rebellion, also known as the First War of Independence.

title: Barrackpore
description: The location where Mangal Pandey, a sepoy, initiated the 1857 Indian Rebellion by attacking his British officers. This event is widely considered the first spark of the rebellion.

title: Wagah Border
description: The border crossing between India and Pakistan, where a daily ceremony is held to symbolize the partition of India in 1947.

title: Rajghat
description: A memorial dedicated to Mahatma Gandhi, located in Delhi. It is the site of his cremation, and a black marble platform marks the spot where he was cremated.

title: India Gate
description: A war memorial located in Delhi, built to commemorate the Indian soldiers who died in World War I. It is a symbol of India's military history and sacrifice.

title: Champaran
description: The site of Gandhi's first Satyagraha (nonviolent protest) in India in 1917, where he protested against the exploitation of indigo farmers by the British.

title: Kakori
description: The site of the 1925 Kakori train robbery, where Indian revolutionaries, including Ram Prasad Bismil and Ashfaqulla Khan, looted a train to fund their independence struggle.

title: Kanpur
description: A key city during the 1857 Indian Rebellion, where a major massacre of British civilians and soldiers took place. It became a symbol of the brutality of the rebellion.

title: Kashi Vishwanath Temple
description: A historic Hindu temple in Varanasi, it holds significance as a center of religious and cultural identity that was often targeted during colonial rule.

title: Chittagong
description: The site of the 1930 Chittagong armoury raid, led by Surya Sen. The raid was a significant armed uprising against the British, showcasing the growing militancy of the independence movement.

title: Mumbai
description: A major hub of the independence movement. It was the site of the Quit India Movement resolution in 1942, and the city saw numerous protests and uprisings against the British.

title: Poona Pact
description: The agreement signed in 1932 between Mahatma Gandhi and B. R. Ambedkar, which established a joint electorate for 'untouchables' while reserving seats for them in the legislature.

title: Amritsar
description: A city in Punjab that is a significant center of Sikhism. It is home to the Golden Temple and was the site of the Jallianwala Bagh massacre.

title: Calcutta
description: The former capital of British India, Calcutta was a major center of political, cultural, and intellectual activity during the independence movement.

title: Lahore
description: A major city in present-day Pakistan, Lahore was an important center of the independence movement. The 1929 Lahore Resolution, which called for complete independence from Britain, was passed here.

title: Swaraj Bhavan
description: The former residence of the Nehru family in Allahabad, it was a central hub for the Indian National Congress and a key meeting place for freedom fighters.

title: Shimla
description: The summer capital of British India, where many important political decisions were made, including the Simla Conference of 1945.

title: Gwalior
description: The location where Rani Lakshmibai of Jhansi died fighting the British during the 1857 Indian Rebellion.

title: Satyagraha Ashram
description: An early ashram established by Mahatma Gandhi in Ahmedabad, where he experimented with his principles of satyagraha.

title: Mahatma Gandhi's birthplace
description: The house in Porbandar, Gujarat, where Mahatma Gandhi was born. It is now a memorial and museum.

title: Viceroy's House
description: Now known as Rashtrapati Bhavan, it was the official residence of the Viceroy of India and became the presidential palace after independence.

title: Parliament House
description: The seat of the Parliament of India, it was formerly the Council House during British rule and witnessed the transfer of power on August 15, 1947.

title: Teen Murti Bhavan
description: The former residence of Jawaharlal Nehru, it is now a museum and library dedicated to his life and the freedom struggle.

title: Agartala
description: The capital of Tripura, it was a princely state that acceded to India after independence. The state played a role in the liberation of Bangladesh from Pakistan.

title: Hyderabad
description: A princely state that resisted joining the Indian Union after independence. It was eventually integrated into India through a military operation in 1948.

title: Junagadh
description: A princely state in Gujarat that was a point of contention during the partition of India. Its ruler wanted to join Pakistan, but the population voted to join India.

title: Kashmir
description: A region that has been a point of conflict between India and Pakistan since the partition of India. It has been the site of numerous wars and a source of political tension.

title: Goa
description: A Portuguese colony that was liberated by India in 1961. The liberation of Goa marked the end of European colonialism in India.

title: Nagpur
description: The headquarters of the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS), a Hindu nationalist organization that played a role in the political landscape of independent India.

title: Bardoli
description: The site of the 1928 Bardoli Satyagraha, a nonviolent protest led by Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel against the British government's unjust tax increase.

title: Madras
description: Now known as Chennai, this city was a major center of anti-colonial protests and the site of the first meeting of the Indian National Congress in 1887.

title: Kheda
description: The site of the 1918 Kheda Satyagraha, a protest organized by Gandhi against the British government's decision to collect taxes despite a crop failure.

title: Meerut
description: The city where the 1857 Indian Rebellion began. Indian sepoys mutinied against their British officers, and the rebellion quickly spread to other parts of the country.

title: Tashkent
description: The city where Indian Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri died in 1966 after signing the Tashkent Declaration with Pakistan to end the 1965 Indo-Pakistani War.

title: Pondicherry
description: A former French colony that was integrated into India in 1954. It is now a Union Territory of India.

title: Kolkata
description: Formerly known as Calcutta, it was the capital of British India until 1911 and a major center of the independence movement.

title: Bhopal
description: A former princely state that was a center of anti-colonial resistance and the site of the Bhopal Gas Tragedy in 1984.

title: Suez Canal
description: A man-made waterway in Egypt that was strategically important for the British Empire as it provided a shorter trade route to India.
